node.title: If It’s Not Critical Race Theory, It’s Critical Race Theory-lite
node.description: The country’s education debate isn’t made up.
node.content: ["Former Gov. Terry McAuliffe lost last week\u2019s Virginia race for governor in part because the victor, Republican newcomer Glenn Youngkin, pledged, \u201cOn Day 1, I will ban critical race theory in our schools.\u201d This followed an October CBS News poll that found that 62 percent of likely Virginia voters considered \u201cschool curriculums on race and history\u201d a \u201cmajor factor\u201d in how they\u2019d vote.", "Yet for some who see racism at play in much of life today, the wokest insight about the result is that a racist backlash against our national racial reckoning cost McAuliffe the election: MSNBC\u2019s Nicolle Wallace concluded \u201cthat the real ominous thing is that critical race theory, which isn\u2019t real, turned the suburbs 15 points to the Trump-insurrection-endorsed Republican.\u201d By ominous, I assume she means that racism was the background issue. On the eve of the election, Fox News\u2019s Juan Williams wrote that Republicans have seized on critical race theory as \u201ca boogeyman to excite racial divisions and get their base to the polls.\u201d", "A common justification for this view is the observation that critical race theory is in fact not being taught in Virginia\u2019s schools or anywhere other than law schools and university seminars and that political opposition to it is cover for something smaller and meaner. That a critical mass of white people doesn\u2019t want schools to teach about the realities of slavery or America\u2019s past racist injustices at all, favoring instead a glossed-over, triumphalist apple-pie-and-Chevrolet narrative.", "The pessimism in this take on America\u2019s racial progress can seem almost fantastical considering clear advances in attitudes about race in recent years: A 2020 Monmouth University poll found that 76 percent \u2014 including 71 percent of white respondents \u2014 considered racial and ethnic discrimination in this country a \u201cbig problem,\u201d compared with just 51 percent who said the same in 2015. Gallup found that from 1958 to 2021, approval of marriage between white and Black people has gone from 4 percent to 94 percent. A July Reuters-Ipsos poll found that 78 percent \u201csupport teaching high school students about the impacts of slavery\u201d and 73 percent support teaching high school students about the impacts of racism.", "It\u2019s reasonable, yes, to note the partisan divide on some of these questions, but less reasonable to suggest that there\u2019s a consensus against any discussion of slavery and racism in schools. Let\u2019s give that suggestion its weight, however: If critical race theory isn\u2019t being taught to children \u2014 and in a technical sense, it isn\u2019t \u2014 then it\u2019s hardly illogical to suppose that some other concern may be afoot.", "The problem lies in the name \u201ccritical race theory.\u201d It\u2019s a no-brainer that the legal doctrine developed decades ago by scholars such as the Harvard Law professor Derrick Bell and the Columbia University and U.C.L.A. law professor Kimberl\u00e9 Crenshaw is not being taught to tots. (Even one of critical race theory\u2019s principal critics, the Manhattan Institute\u2019s Christopher Rufo, has acknowledged that he\u2019s tried to make \u201ccritical race theory\u201d a catchall term.) But today, this isn\u2019t what most voters mean when they object to critical race theory, and to participate in this debate as if otherwise is quibbling at best, and a smoke screen at worst.", "Sunday night, Crenshaw defined critical race theory this way to MSNBC\u2019s Mehdi Hasan:", "OK. But consider the cultural critic Helen Pluckrose\u2019s \u2014 fair, I think \u2014 summary of the original body of critical race theory work:", "It\u2019s difficult, certainly, to imagine a grade-school teacher in front of a classroom teaching this kind of thing. However, this \u201ccritical\u201d approach has trickled down, in broad outline, into the philosophy of education-school pedagogy and administration \u2014 call it C.R.T.-lite or, if you prefer, C.R.T. Jr. \u2014 and from there migrated into the methods used by graduates of those education programs into the way they wind up running schools.", "Under this approach, what alarms many parents and other observers is that kids will absorb the idea that it is enlightened to see white people as potential oppressors and Black people as perpetual victims of an inherently oppressive system. That it is therefore appropriate to ascribe certain traits to races, rather than individuals, and that education must \u201ccenter\u201d the battle against power differentials between groups and the subtle perceptions that they condition.", "An implication some educators draw from these tenets is that various expectations of some of their students, based on what are generally thought to be ordinary mainstream assumptions, are instead onerous stipulations from an oppressive white-centric view. Hence an idea that it is white to be on time, arrive at precise answers and reason from A to B, rather than holistically, etc. Again, this is not what decades-old critical race theory scholarship proposed, but yes, the idea is descended from original C.R.T.\u2019s fundamental propositions about white supremacy.", "In Virginia itself, the Department of Education\u2019s website has a page devoted to \u201cAnti-racism in Education,\u201d and at the end of a long list of \u201cTerms and Definitions\u201d it reads, \u201cDrawing from critical race theory, the term \u2018white supremacy\u2019 also refers to a political or socio-economic system where white people enjoy structural advantage and rights that other racial and ethnic groups do not, both at a collective and an individual level.\u201d", "In the 2022 draft revision of the California Department of Education\u2019s \u201cMathematics Framework,\u201d the chapter on \u201cTeaching for Equity and Engagement\u201d includes this language: \u201cEmpowering students with mathematics also includes removing the high stakes of errors and sending the message that learning is always unfinished and that it is safe to take mathematical risks. This mind-set creates the conditions for students to develop a sense of ownership over their mathematical thinking and their right to belong to the discipline of mathematics\u201d \u2014 a truly artful way of saying that \u201cdiverse\u201d kids should not be saddled with the onerous task of having to get the actual answers.", "In February, the Oregon Department of Education sent an update to math educators that linked to a document titled \u201cA Pathway to Equitable Math Instruction/Dismantling Racism in Mathematics Instruction.\u201d It contains a section on \u201cDeconstructing Racism in Mathematics Instruction\u201d positing that \u201cwhite supremacy culture in the mathematics classroom can show up\u201d in a variety of ways, including when \u201cPreconceived expectations are steeped in the dominant culture,\u201d \u201cSuperficial curriculum changes are offered in place of culturally relevant pedagogy and practice\u201d and \u201cStudents are required to \u2018show their work\u2019 in standardized, prescribed ways.\u201d", "Perhaps a reasonable objection would be that these are only teacher guidelines and that we cannot know exactly how, or whether, teachers are adhering to them in classrooms. But these guidelines, apparently sanctioned by state departments of education, contradict the notion that concepts derived from critical race theory \u2014 or are, at least, C.R.T.-lite \u2014 is nowhere near our schools, that the C.R.T.-in-schools debate \u201cisn\u2019t real,\u201d merely a fiction designed to cloak racism.", "In some cases, evidence of C.R.T.-lite is easier to spot at various private schools. Granted, governors can\u2019t \u201cban\u201d private school curriculums, but the experience at some tony New York prep schools, for instance, demonstrates how C.R.T.-lite isn\u2019t simply found in teacher trainings but can make its way into the classroom and schools\u2019 educational philosophy. As The Times reported earlier this year:", "Some of those who say that critical race theory isn\u2019t being taught in schools may not be aware of these developments. Others most likely are, and suppose that they are healthy, that this is indeed how education should be.", "That\u2019s a respectable stance, but one ought not harbor it in disbelief that any intelligent, morally concerned person could feel differently. One can ardently support that students learn about racism and its legacies in a way that doesn\u2019t crowd out obvious lessons about the history of undeniable racial progress. One can do that while questioning whether students should be immersed in a broader perspective that offers overbroad, clumsy and, frankly, insulting portraits of what is inherently white and what is Black, Latino, Asian American or Native American, and fosters \u2014 even if unintentional \u2014 a sense of opposition between the groups in question.", "To be sure, voices on the political right, including Youngkin, must do better when it comes to specifying what they oppose. They, and we, would be better off if they explained that they oppose philosophies influenced by critical race theory, rather than claiming C.R.T. itself is being taught. Bills intended to ban the teaching of C.R.T.-lite shouldn\u2019t be worded as if the intent was to ban the teaching of anything about race at all. And if that\u2019s what any of these bills do mean, they should spell it out in clear language in order to expose that intent to debate \u2014 one within which I would be vociferously opposed, I should note. The horror of slavery, the hypocrisy of Jim Crow, the terror of lynching, the devastating loss of life and property in Tulsa and in other massacres \u2014 no student should get through, roughly, middle school ignorant of these things, and anyone who thinks that is \u201cpolitics\u201d needs to join the rest of us in the 21st century.", "But the insistence that parents opposed to what is being called critical race theory are rising against a mere fantasy and simply enjoying a coded way of fostering denial about race is facile. It is an attempt to wrest a woke object lesson from the nuanced realities of life as it is actually lived, in which the notion of a white backlash against racial progress may appeal as narrative, or as analysis of an electoral upset, but rarely tracks with on-the-ground reality."]
